Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on personal conversations and an annual report of the 50 wealthiest members of Congress, which may not provide a comprehensive picture of the wealth of all members.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that being classified as wealthy is the only criteria for determining if someone is wealthy, which may not be accurate.
Exist alternative explanation: There could be alternative explanations for the claim, such as different definitions of wealth or different criteria for classifying someone as wealthy.
Understate: The claim may understate the percentage of wealthy individuals in the House, as the expert challenges the congressman's claim as erroneous and "out of touch."
Falters at times: The claim may falter at times as it is based on personal conversations and a single annual report, which may not provide a comprehensive and accurate assessment of the wealth of all members of the House.
Contradict fact: It is unclear if the claim contradicts any specific facts, as the information provided does not include concrete evidence to support or refute the claim.
Exaggerate: The claim does not appear to exaggerate the percentage of wealthy individuals in the House, as it states that fewer than 10 percent would classify as wealthy.
